newsitem.title: THAILAND: FORECAST-Oil price rise may push up Thai C/A gap.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST-Oil price rise may push up Thai C/A gap.

text.p: Seamico Research said on Friday that rising oil prices could further widen Thailand's current account deficit to nine percent of gross domestic product for 1996 from 8.1 percent in 1995.
Seamico said in a research report that the recent oil price increases would drive import figures even higher against a backdrop of sliding export growth.
Exports grew only two percent during the first seven months of 1996, compared with 8.1 percent during the same period last year, it said.
But import growth has been driven by two primary factors: oil price increases and strengthening of the baht against the yen which will encourage more imports, it said.

The worsening deficit will increase speculation about a baht devaluation. Meanwhile, the present tight liquidity conditions are expected to worsen in the last quarter, putting upward pressure on local interest rates, Seamico said.
